Award.AwardTitle: Atmospheric Hydrocarbons at GEOSummit, Greenland, as Tracers for Climate Change, Air Pollution Transport, and Oxidation Chemistry in the Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study is a contribution to the Arctic Observing Network (AON). It will undertake 4 years of continuous measurements of atmospheric methane, and non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHC; ethane, ethyne, propane, iso-butane, n-butane, iso-pentane, n-pentane, benzene, toluene) at the Greenland Environmental Observatory at Summit (GEOSummit). An existing monitoring system that has previously been operated at Summit for two seasons will be deployed. This gas chromatography instrument is specifically tailored towards operation at this remote arctic site, as it is fully automated and remotely controllable. This instrument uses a minimal amount of power and does not require cryogen and compressed gas supplies, which make it highly favorable and cost efficient for Summit conditions. A second analytical channel will be added to include monitoring of the important climate gas methane with the same instrument.

Intellectual Merits: This project will deliver 4 years of continuous atmospheric concentration data of methane, with approximately 2 hour time resolution, and nine C2-C7 NMHC at low parts per trillion sensitivity (for NMHC) at Summit. These data will expand upon the previous 2008-2010 NMHC measurements from Summit, and will provide an overall 8 year (with a 2 year gap) record for these gases.

Broader Impacts: These measurements will be highly complementary to the NMHC monitoring within the NOAA-INSTAAR global flask sampling program, which, for the past 7 years, has provided bi-weekly NMHC data for five arctic sites. The much higher resolution in-situ data from this study will add value to the interpretation of the NMHC flask records. By applying chemical transport modeling, the in-situ data will allow researchers to decipher air pollution transport into the Arctic and contributions from different emission source region contributions at lower latitudes. The methane and NMHC monitoring will make a pivotal contribution to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) Global Atmospheric Watch (GAW) Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) program, as it will provide the only high time resolution in-situ NMHC site in the Arctic. This observational activity will also be presented in class room teaching and seminars and be incorporated in INSTAAR?s outreach program, i.e. on the ?Ozone and Snow? educational website. This project will promote a new collaboration between INSTAAR at the University of Colorado and atmospheric researchers at EMPA, Switzerland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over a total of seven years atmospheric concentrations of methane and of non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHC; these include heavier (larger molecule) compounds, such as ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, benzene, toluene) were measured at the Global Atmospheric Watch station Summit, located at 3215 m above sea level on the center/apex of the Greenland Ice Sheet.   A fully automated and remotely controlled (via an internet connection) instrument was installed in May 2012 in the TAWO building, and then operated continuously, around the clock, day after day, requiring only 1-2 ~1-week site visits every year for instrument maintenance.  Measurements were done in high time resolution, every few hours, resulting in more than 50.000 individual methane, and more than 10.000 individual NMHC data points.   >95% data coverage was achieved over the project period.   A quality audit by the World Calibration Centre for Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) in August 2017 showed that all NMHC measurements met the quality guidelines set by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) Global Atmospheric Watch (GAW) program.  In summary, the monitoring records obtained within the framework of this project are the richest and highest accuracy measurements of this type ever accomplished in the Arctic.

The data have been used in research on pollution transport, atmospheric chemistry, and climate change.  

These measurements serve as the reference point for a global network, encompassing some 40 other global network sites, where much lower time resolution monitoring is done by collecting air into flasks that are then shipped to Boulder for analysis in a central laboratory.  The side-by-side measurements at Summit serve as the quality control and calibration reference for atmospheric concentrations and trends seen at the global sites.

On the order of ten peer reviewed publications have been produced over the past five years building on this project.   These include three publications in the prestigious journal Nature.   The primary findings presented in these publications are:

-          We defined the comparability between the high accuracy in-situ monitoring at Summit and the global flask sample collection, demonstrating an overall high level of agreement.

-          We demonstrated that atmospheric NMHC, after a ~30 years period of decline, suddenly started increasing again around 2009.  This reversal in atmospheric trends has been tied to increased emissions from growing oil and gas industries, largely in North America.

-          Comparison of atmospheric NMHC concentrations with model simulations showed that models significantly underestimate the monitoring data.  Three independent studies all have concluded that this is due to an underestimation of global emission sources of NMHC.

-          Occurrences of elevated methane and NMHC concentrations at Summit were traced to smoke transport from tundra wildfires in coastal Greenland.  This observations demonstrate the long-distance transport and large geographical impact of pollution from the burning tundra.   Wildfires have been and are expected to increase further from climate change.   This therefore constitutes a thus far poorly defined climate feedback, where the smoke and deposited soot from the wildfires potentially will further accelerate warming and melting of Arctic glaciers and the Greenland ice shield.

This monitoring project and results were highlighted in the first Global Atmospheric Watch Bulletin for Reactive Gases, published in May, 2017 (https://public.wmo.int/en/media/news/wmogaw-launches-first-issue-of-reactive-gases-bulletin).  Data have been quality controlled and submitted to the World Data Centre for Greenhouse Gases and the Arctic Data Centre for free and unrestricted use by the global research community.
